text.p: ** BIRTHDAYS **
English social reformer JOSEPHINE BUTLER, who campaigned for womens' rights, was born in 1828.
English composer SIR ARTHUR SULLIVAN was born in 1842.
French painter GEORGES BRAQUE, who was the first living artist to have his work displayed in the Louvre and who jointly created 'cubism' with PABLO PICASSO, was born in 1882.

Australian swimming champion SIR FRANK BEAUREPAIRE, who competed in the Olympics of 1908, 1920 and 1924 (he held 15 world records but never won a gold medal), was born in 1892. The International Swimming Federation robbed him of his amateur status in June 1914, claiming he was a swimming teacher, but BEAUREPAIRE returned in 1920, defeating American champion NORMAN ROSS over 880 yards at Saint Kilda Baths. On the 4th of February 1922, BEAUREPAIRE and a life saver rescued 19 year-old MICHAEL COGHLAN, who'd been attacked by a shark during a water carnival off Sydney's Coogee Beach. Despite their heroic efforts to save him while the shark continued its attack, COGHLAN died within

minutes of reaching hospital. BEAUREPAIRE established the (aptly named) Olympic Tyre Company in 1933, and died on the 19th of May 1956 (at the age of 65), just months before Melbourne staged the Olympic Games which he had assisted in bringing to Australia.
American world heavyweight boxing champion JOE LOUIS, who was known as the "Brown Bomber", was born in 1914.
American actress BEA ARTHUR (The "Golden Girls") was born in 1926.
Australian Liberal politician JIM CARLTON was born in 1935.
Composer NIGEL BUTTERLY was born in Sydney in 1935. He worked for the ABC before moving to London in 1961.

American singer RITCHIE VALENS, whose biggest hits were "Donna" and "La Bomba" and who died with BUDDY HOLLY and J. P. "Big Bopper" RICHARDSON when their light plane crashed near Mason City, Iowa on the 3rd of February 1959, was born in 1941.
British pop musician JACK BRUCE, best known as a member of the group "Cream", was born in 1943.
American singer STEVIE WONDER, who was born STEVELAND JUDKINS MORRIS and had his first hit at the age of 12 with "Fingertips", was born in 1950.
English singer PETER GABRIEL, who went on to a successful solo career after breaking from the band "Genesis", was born in 1950.
** EVENTS **
1607 : Captain JOHN SMITH and a party of soldiers landed
in Virginia at Jamestown and established the first permanent British settlement in the New World.
1787 : The first fleet of ships carrying convicts to the
the new penal colony of Australia left England. They arrived the following January.
1830 : The Republic of Ecuador was created on the
break-up of the original state of Gran Colombia.
1835 : English architect JOHN NASH, who was commissioned
by KING GEORGE IV to redevelop parts of London including Regent Street and Trafalgar Square, died.
1927 : "Black Friday" occurred in Germany, signalling the
collapse of its economic structure.
1930 : Norwegian explorer FRIDTJOF NANSEN, who won the
Nobel Peace prize in 1923 for introducing the 'Nansen Passport' for displaced persons, (while he was the League Of Nations' High Commissioner for Refugees) died.
1940 : After setting up Britain's wartime coalition,
WINSTON CHURCHILL told parliament he could offer "....nothing but blood, toil, tears and sweat".
1943 : The Italian Commander-in-Chief in Tunisia
surrendered a day after his German counterpart, with the Allies holding some 250,000 prisoners of war.
1961 : U.S. film actor GARY COOPER, who won Oscars for
his roles in the films "Sergeant York" and "High Noon", died at 60.
1962 : Indonesian President SUKARNO escaped unhurt from
an assassination attempt.
1968 : American and North Vietnamese diplomats met in
Paris to start peace negotiations. The North Vietnamese refused to discuss anything of substance until the United States stopped its bombing raids of their country.
1971 : On his 21st birthday, STEVIE WONDER (see above)
received one-million dollars as his childhood earnings (even though he'd earned more than 30-million dollars).
1981 : POPE JOHN PAUL II was shot 4 times by 23 year old

Turkish gunman MEHMET ALI AGCA. The POPE was travelling through a crowd of 20,000 people in St Peter's Square in Rome when he was shot. Two women standing near the open-top Papal jeep were wounded in the shooting.
1989 : Former British pilot JACKIE MANN was kidnapped in
Beirut.
1990 : A car bomb exploded in the Colombian capital
Bogota, killing 26 people.
1994 : Austrian formula one driver KARL WENDLINGER
suffered serious head injuries when he crashed during practice for the Monaco Grand Prix.
